name: Segmentation
rules: A. Divide an object into independent parts.
B. Make an object easy to disassemble.
C. Increase the degree of fragmentation or segmentation.
description: Divide an object into independent parts or increase its degree of segmentation.

name: Taking Out
rules: A. Extract the "disturbing" part or property from an object
B. Extract only the necessary part or property from an object
description: Separate an interfering part or single out the only necessary part of an object.

name: Local Quality
rules: A. Transition from homogenous to heterogenous structure of an object or outside environment
B. Different parts of an object should carry out different functions
C. Each part of an object should be placed in conditions that are the most favorable for its operation
description: Change an object's structure from uniform to non-uniform, making each part fulfill a useful function.

name: Asymmetry
rules: A. Replace symmetrical form(s) with asymmetrical form(s).
B. If an object is already asymmetrical, increase its degree of asymmetry.
description: Change the shape of an object from symmetrical to asymmetrical to improve functionality.

name: Consolidation
rules: A. Consolidate in space homogeneous objects or objects destined for contiguous operations.
B. Consolidate in time homogeneous or contiguous operations.
description: Bring similar objects closer to perform parallel operations or make operations contiguous.

name: Universality
rules: A. An object can perform several different functions; therefore, other elements can be removed
description: Make a part or object perform multiple functions, eliminating the need for other parts.

name: Nesting
rules: A. One object is placed inside another. That object is placed inside a third one. And so on...
B. One object passes through a cavity in another object.
description: Place one object inside another or make one part pass through a cavity in another.

name: Counterweight
rules: A. Compensate for the weight of an object by combining it with another object that provides a lifting force
B. Compensate for the weight of an object with aerodynamic or hydrodynamic forces influenced by the outside environment
description: Compensate for the weight of an object by merging it with others that provide lift or interact with the environment.

name: Prior Counteraction
rules: A. Preload countertension to an object to compensate excessive and undesirable stress.
description: Replace an action with harmful effects with anti-actions to control these effects.

name: Prior Action
rules: A. Proform required changes to an object completely or partially in advance.
B. Place objects in advance so that they can go into action immediately from the most convenient location
description: Perform required changes to an object beforehand to avoid problems during use.

name: Cushion in advance
rules: A. Compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object with emergency measures prepared in advance.
description: Prepare emergency measures to compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object.

name: Equipotentiality
rules: A. Change the conditions of the work in such a way that it will not require lifting or lowering an object
description: Change conditions to avoid the need for lifting or moving an object.

name: Do it in Reverse
rules: A. Instead of the direct action dictated by a problem, implement an opposite action (i.e., cooling instead of heating)
B. Make the moveable part of an object, or outside environment, stationary - and the stationary part moveable.
C. Turn an object upside-sown or apply reverse action.
description: Reverse the usual process or way to achieve the desired effect.

name: Spheroidality
rules: A. Replace linear parts with curved parts, flat surfaces with spherical surfaces, and cube shapes with ball shapes.
B. Use rollers, balls, spirals.
C. Replace linear motion with rotational motion; utilize centrifugal force.
description: Go from flat surfaces to spherical forms or use rollers, balls, spirals.

name: Dynamicity
description: Make objects or environments capable of changing to be useful under different conditions.

name: Partial or Excessive Action
rules: A. If it is difficult to obtain 100% of a desired effect, achieve more or less of the desired effect.
description: If 100% of an object is hard to achieve, use a little less or a bit more to suffice.

name: Transition into a New Dimension
rules: A. Transition one-dimensional movement, or placement, of objects into two-dimensional; two-dimensional to three-dimensional, etc.
B. Utilize multi-level composition of objects.
C. Incline an object or place it on its side.
D. Utilize the opposite side of a given surface.
E. Project optical lines onto neighboring areas, or onto the reverse side of an object.
description: Use aspects of 3D space or other directions/multiples to solve a problem.

name: Mechanical Vibration
rules: A. Utilize oscillation.
B. If oscillation exists, increase its frequency to ultrasonic.
C. Use the frequency of resonance.
D. Replace mechanical vibrations with piezo-vibrations.
E. Use ultrasonic vibrations in conjunction with an electromagnetic field.
description: Use oscillations or resonances to improve processes.

name: Periodic Action
rules: A. Replace a continuous action with a periodic one (impulse).
B. If the action is already periodic, change its frequency.
C. Use pauses between impulses to provide additional action.
description: Replace continuous action with periodic ones or use pauses between impulses to save resources.

name: Continuity of Useful Action
rules: A. Carry out an action without a break. All parts of the object should constantly operate at full capacity.
B. Remove idle and intermediate motion.
C. Replace "back-and-forth" motion with a rotating one.
description: Make all parts of an object work at full load, eliminating idle or intermittent actions.

name: Rushing Through
rules: A. Perform harmful and hazardous operations at a very high speed.
description: Conduct processes, or certain stages of processes, without intermediate steps.

name: Convert Harm into Benefit
rules: A. Utilize harmful factors- especially environmental- to obtain a positive effect.
B. Remove one harmful factor by combining it with another harmful factor.
C. Increase the degree of harmful action to such an extent that it ceases to be harmful.
description: Utilize harmful factors, particularly environmental, to achieve a positive effect.

name: Feedback
rules: A. Introduce feedback.
B. If feedback already exists, change it.
description: Introduce feedback to modify a process or enhance a reaction.

name: Mediator
rules: A. Use an intermediary object to transfer or carry-out an action.
B. Temporarily connect the original object to one that is easily removed.
description: Use an intermediate carrier or process to transfer or temporarily store energy.

name: Self Service
rules: A. An object must service itself and carry-out supplementary and repair operations.
B. Make use of waste material and energy.
description: Allow objects to serve themselves by performing auxiliary helpful functions.

name: Copying
rules: A. A simplified and inexpensive copy should be used in place of a fragile original or an object that is inconvenient to operate.
B. If a visible optical copy is used, replace it with an infrared or ultraviolet copy.
C. Replace an object (or system of objects) with their optical image. The image can then be reduced or enlarged.
description: Use cheaper or simpler replicas of an object or process where less precision is needed.

name: Disposable
rules: A. Replace an expensive object with a cheap one, compromising other properties (i.e., longevity)
description: Replace expensive objects with inexpensive ones to reduce cost, even if it means a shorter lifespan.

name: Replacement of Mechanical System
rules: A. Replace a mechanical system with an optical, acoustical, thermal or olfactory system.
B. Use an electric, magnetic or electromagnetic field to interact with an object.
C. Replace fields that are:
- Stationary with mobile.
- Fixed with changing in time.
- Random with structured.
D. Use fields in conjunction with ferromagnetic particles.
description: Replace a mechanical means with a sensory (optical, acoustic, taste, or olfactory) method.

name: Pneumatic or Hydraulic Construction
rules: A. Replace solid parts of an object with a gas or liquid. These parts can now use air or water for inflation, or use pneumatic or hydrostatic cushion.
description: Use gases and liquids to achieve or improve function instead of solid parts.

name: Flexible Membranes or Thin Films
rules: A. Replace customary constructions with flexible membranes or thin films.
B. Isolate an object from its outside environment with flexible membranes or thin films.
description: Use flexible materials to replace traditional rigid materials.

name: Porous Material
rules: A. Make an object porous, or use supplementary porous elements (inserts, covers, etc.).
B. If an object is already porous, fill pores in advance with some substance.
description: Make an object porous or add porous elements to introduce a new effect (e.g., absorption).

name: Changing the Color
rules: A. Change the color of an object or its environment.
B. Change the degree of translucency of an object or its environment.
C. Use color additives to observe an object, or process, which is difficult to see.
D. If such additives are already used, employ luminescent traces or trace atoms.
description: Use color changes to improve the visibility of changes or indicate control processes.

name: Homogeneity
rules: A. Objects interacting with the main object should be made out of the same material (or material with similar properties) as the main object.
description: Make materials interacting with an object have similar physical properties to reduce problems.

name: Rejecting and Regenerating Parts
rules: A. After completing its function, or becoming useless, an element of an object is rejected (discarded, dissolved, evaporated, etc.) or modified during its work process.
B. Used-up parts of an object should be restored during its work.
description: Make parts of an object that have fulfilled their functions easily recoverable or replaceable.

name: Transformation of Properties
rules: A. Change the physical state of the system.
B. Change the concentration or density.
C. Change the degree of flexibility.
description: Change an object's physical state (e.g., temperature, concentration, density) to improve its performance.

name: Phase Transition
rules: A. Use the phenomena of phase change (i.e., a change in volume, the liberation or absorption of heat, etc.)
description: Use phenomena occurring during phase transitions (e.g., volume changes, energy absorption/release).

name: Thermal Expansion
rules: A. Use expansion or contraction of material by changing its temperature.
B. Use various materials with different coefficients of thermal expansion.
description: Use thermal expansion or contraction of materials to move or reshape objects.

name: Accelerated Oxidation
rules: A. Make transition from one level of oxidation to the next higher level:
- Ambient air to oxygenated.
- Oxygenated to oxygen.
- Oxygen to ionized oxygen.
- Ionized oxygen to ozoned oxygen.
- Ozoned oxygen to ozone.
- Ozone to singlet oxygen.
description: Use strong oxidants to speed up a reaction or process.

name: Inert Environment
rules: A. Replace a normal environment with an inert one.
B. Introduce a neutral substance or additives into an object.
C. Carry out a process in a vacuum.
description: Perform a process in an inert atmosphere to prevent undesirable reactions or changes.

name: CompositeStructures
rules: A. Replace homogeneous materials with composite ones.
description: Use composite materials to achieve the optimal combination of properties not available in any single material.
